title: fragment shader position.z is scaled to viewport mindepth -> maxdepth

milestone.title: V1.0
milestone.description: Issues which at least one party wishes to make it into Version 1 of the API.

body:
Currently the API spec says:

position is set to:
vec4<f32>(rp.[destination](https://gpuweb.github.io/gpuweb/#rasterizationpoint-destination).[position](https://gpuweb.github.io/gpuweb/#fragmentdestination-position), rp.[depth](https://gpuweb.github.io/gpuweb/#rasterizationpoint-depth), rp.[perspectiveDivisor](https://gpuweb.github.io/gpuweb/#rasterizationpoint-perspectivedivisor))

And that rp.depth is the NDC depth.

But Vulkan and D3D say it's already been scaled by the viewport.

Vulkan: see https://registry.khronos.org/vulkan/specs/1.3-extensions/html/vkspec.html#vertexpostproc-viewport   zf = pz * zd + oz
And then FragCoord says the x,y,z are the "framebuffer coordinates", thus referencing xf, yf, zf.

In the D3D11 functional spec, see computation of xrt, yrt, zrt in "15.6 Viewport"

https://microsoft.github.io/DirectX-Specs/d3d/archive/D3D11_3_FunctionalSpec.htm#16.3%20Pixel%20Shader%20Inputs

title: editorial: Texel format and access mode are not context-dependent names

milestone.title: V1.0
milestone.description: Issues which at least one party wishes to make it into Version 1 of the API.

body:
Fix the text in the description of storage textures.

Fixes: #3963

title: editorial: texel format, access mode are not context-dependent names anymore

milestone.title: V1.0
milestone.description: Issues which at least one party wishes to make it into Version 1 of the API.

body: The storage texture types section says that texel format and access modes are context-dependent names. They are not anymore.

title: Fix template list discovery, to recognize embedded comparisons and shifts

milestone.title: V1.0
milestone.description: Issues which at least one party wishes to make it into Version 1 of the API.

body:
- Describe high level assumptions and properties of template lists
  - template parameters only contain expressions
  - expressions don't contain assignments, or colon, semicolon, or left brace.
  - expressions don't start with = or <
  - The only time '=' appears is as part of a comparison operation Before, '=' was always seen as the end of all unclosed template candidates. But we need to handle != == >= <= as relational operators in expressions as template args. So various cases need to see and skip over '='.

Adjust the algorithm to handle the above cases.

The spec part of #3868

title: wgsl: template list discovery doesn't handle relational expressions in templates, when they have '=' in the token

milestone.title: V1.0
milestone.description: Issues which at least one party wishes to make it into Version 1 of the API.

title: wgsl: Concretization must be concrete

milestone.title: V1.0
milestone.description: Issues which at least one party wishes to make it into Version 1 of the API.

title: grammar analyzer: Fix first and follow sets for degenerate rules
body:
Sometimes handwritten grammars have simple rules like:
    
        A -> B
    
    or
        C -> D | ....
    
    where B and D are symbols.
    
    The First and Follow sets were not propagating across that kind of
    construction.  Normally a rule is constructed canonically as a choice
    over sequences. But in this case the rule is itself a single "Symbol"
    or a choice where one of the alternatives is just a Symbol.
    
    The First set of B should propagate to the First set of A.
    The First set of D should propagate to the First set of C.
    
    The Follow set of A should propagate to the Follow set of B.
    The Follow set of C should propagate to the Follow set of D.
    
    Also fix dumping a grammar to stdout.

title: wgsl: Fix description of atomicCompareExchangeWeak
body: The original value is compared to `cmp`, not `v`.

title: wgsl: comparison operator result is scalar bool when "is scalar" should expand to include abstract numerics.

milestone.title: V1.0
milestone.description: Issues which at least one party wishes to make it into Version 1 of the API.

body:
"Scalar" actually excludes AbstractInt, AbstractFloat
But    a == b should yield bool when a and b are AbstractInt or AbstractFloat.

This was missed in the update to add abstract numerics.

title: In type rule for boolean negation (`!`), use `T` in precondition.
body: The rule as written doesn't permit `!` on `vecN<bool>`.

title: change endPass() to end() in IDL
body:
#2560 changed endPass() to end() but did not update the IDL.
This is on GPUComputePassEncoder and GPURenderPassEncoder

The lack of an end() method breaks the dawn_node build.

I think the minimum fix is to add end().
If we want a deprecation period, then delete endPass() later; otherwise delete it now.

title: Require that 1D texture have a single mipmap.

milestone.title: V1.0
milestone.description: Issues which at least one party wishes to make it into Version 1 of the API.

body:
Adding CTS tests for 1D textures I found the following Metal Debug Device validation:

```
MTLTextureDescriptor requests a mipmapLevelCount of 3 but the texture type MTLTextureType1D requires that mipmapLevelCount is 1
```

title: in certain contexts, an identifier does not resolve to its declared object

milestone.title: V1.0
milestone.description: Issues which at least one party wishes to make it into Version 1 of the API.

body:
> When an identifier is used, it must be in scope for some declaration, or as part of a directive. When an identifier is used in scope of one or more declarations for that name, the identifier will denote the object of the non-module-scope declaration appearing closest to that use, or the module-scope declaration if no other declaration is in scope. We say the identifier use resolves to that declaration.

This is not quite right, unfortunately.

Example 1:
```rust
let rgba8unorm: i32 = 12;
[[group(0),binding(0)]] var texture_storage_2d<rgba8unorm,write>; 
// this use of rgba8unorm does not denote the value 12.
```

Example 2:
```rust
let binding: i32 = 1;

[[group(0),binding(0)]] var texture_storage_2d<rgba8unorm,write>; 
// this use of binding does not denote the value 1
```

Example 3:
```rust
enable foobar;      // this use of foobar does not denote the value 1
let foobar: i32 = 1;
```

In each case the scope of the declaration includes the uses of the identifier, but the identifier does not denote the declared object.
Basically, we need to describe spots in the source text where the normal identifier resolution rules are not active.  These would be:  
- in the text of a directive
- attribute names
- parameters to certain attributes: interpolate, stage, builtin
- texel format part of a storage texture type

title: Specification unclear on weather rendering into 3D textures is allowed

milestone.title: V1.0
milestone.description: Issues which at least one party wishes to make it into Version 1 of the API.

body: https://gpuweb.github.io/gpuweb/#abstract-opdef-gpurenderpasscolorattachment-gpurenderpasscolorattachment-valid-usage and https://gpuweb.github.io/gpuweb/#abstract-opdef-gpurenderpassdepthstencilattachment-gpurenderpassdepthstencilattachment-valid-usage should make clear that views into 3D textures are not allowed.

title: wgsl: plural form `attribute_lists` should be explicitly explained somewhere

milestone.title: V1.0
milestone.description: Issues which at least one party wishes to make it into Version 1 of the API.

body:
https://github.com/gpuweb/gpuweb/blob/52c1f0dfe2d4ccb37f700147dbf3951cc10a2fca/wgsl/index.bs#L1187

https://github.com/gpuweb/gpuweb/blob/52c1f0dfe2d4ccb37f700147dbf3951cc10a2fca/wgsl/index.bs#L1244

https://github.com/gpuweb/gpuweb/blob/52c1f0dfe2d4ccb37f700147dbf3951cc10a2fca/wgsl/index.bs#L1254

etc. (9 of them) all link to [attribute_list](https://gpuweb.github.io/gpuweb/wgsl/#syntax-attribute_list). The text of the link should be corrected.

title: Validate that requested alignment limits are power of two

milestone.title: V1.0
milestone.description: Issues which at least one party wishes to make it into Version 1 of the API.

body: Right now we only require that requested limits are no better than what the adapter supports. However I think we should also require that alignments are power of two as they don't make much sense otherwise.

title: Interpolate attribute clarification
Should we constrain the location of user input-output stage variables WGSL

milestone.title: V1.0
milestone.description: Issues which at least one party wishes to make it into Version 1 of the API.

body:
While implementing `maxInterStageShaderComponents` @Jiawei-Shao noticed that Vulkan had some constraints on the location of shader input/output variables:

> According to Vulkan SPEC, "Each effective Location must have a value less than the number of location available for the given interface"

This means that Vulkan requires that the location be less than `maxInterStageShaderComponents / 4`, at least at first glance. I believe that since we require that interfaces match exactly between shaders, we can, during `createShaderModule`, renumber the IO variables of entrypoints and pack them in `maxInterStageShaderComponents / 4` `vec4` but that's a bit complicated and could be done post-MVP.

Any concerns with adding a limitations that locations must be less than `maxInterStageShaderComponents / 4`?

title: Invariant attributes usage
body:
a) Invariant attributes must only be applied to the position built-in variable.
b) position built-in can be used as vertex shader output or fragment shader input. 
spect only explains what it means if it is used on a vertex shader output.

Fix: explicitly say that it can only be used with vertex shader.

title: Clarify the vertex stage output / fragment stage input matching rules

milestone.title: V1.0
milestone.description: Issues which at least one party wishes to make it into Version 1 of the API.

body:
We need to clarify the vertex stage output / fragment stage input matching rules as currently they are confusing in WebGPU and WGSL SPEC.

- In [WebGPU SPEC](https://gpuweb.github.io/gpuweb/#abstract-opdef-validating-gpurenderpipelinedescriptor): 
  - For each user-defined output of descriptor.vertex there must be a user-defined input of descriptor.fragment that matches the location, type, and interpolation of the output.
  - For each user-defined input of descriptor.fragment there must be a user-defined output of descriptor.vertex that location, type, and interpolation of the input.

- In [WGSL SPEC](https://gpuweb.github.io/gpuweb/wgsl/#pipeline-compatibility):
  - user data inputs of fragment stage must be subset of user data outputs of vertex stage

title: cleanup - textureSample*() offset argument limitations
body:
In https://www.w3.org/TR/WGSL/#texturesample: 
Offset parameter for texturesample*() is always multidimensional, so 'literal' can be removed.
'compile time constant' is never defined in scope.

title: Invalid Web IDL: maxComputeWorkgroupSize cannot be a dictionary type
body:
#1898 introduced `maxComputeWorkgroupSize` of type `GPUExtent3D`, which is a dictionary:
https://github.com/gpuweb/gpuweb/blob/main/spec/index.bs#L1291

But the type of an attribute cannot resolve to a dictionary type in Web IDL (see https://heycam.github.io/webidl/#idl-attributes). The Web IDL parser chokes on this construct as a result.

Main reason why Web IDL forbids that is that there would then be no easy way to enforce that the same object would be returned when the attribute gets accessed multiple times (i.e. that `obj.maxComputeWorkgroupSize === obj.maxComputeWorkgroupSize`), which is what developers expect with attributes, see [Attributes should behave like data properties](https://w3ctag.github.io/design-principles/#attributes-like-data) in the TAG's design principles.

Main alternatives would be to use a method or to go to one level deeper with properties such as `maxComputeWorkgroupSizeWidth`, `maxComputeWorkgroupSizeHeight`, `maxComputeWorkgroupDepthOrArrayLayers`.

title: Operations happening in GPUVertexState are underspecified
body:
Noticed this during a discussion with @ben-clayton about how to implement programmable vertex pulling in Metal.

A lot of things should be detailed on how `GPUVertexState` operates. We discussed some of these issues in the past but needed and investigation. I wrote pretty detailed CTS operation tests that pass on all systems and confirmed a lot of contraints / behavior of the APIs.

 - [ ] `GPUVertexFormat` and shader input variable matching rules (confirmed that only the base type needs to match)
 - [ ] what happens when the number of components of `GPUVertexFormat` and the shader input variable don't match (confirmed either drops components, or fills unspecified components with y->0 z->0 w->1).
 - [ ] what input variables are considered, currently the spec still mentions static use, which is outdated with the new IO entrypoints.
 - [ ] what is the packing of vertex formats in memory (confirmed it is x, y, z, w in that order in memory)
 - [ ] how are each of the `GPUVertexFormat` interpreted? (confirmed the corner case that snorm gets clamped to [-1, 1])
 - [ ] other stuff I'm missing?

We should improve the specification in that area.

title: Remove the requirement for Vulkan's drawIndirectFirstInstance feature.

milestone.title: V1.0
milestone.description: Issues which at least one party wishes to make it into Version 1 of the API.

body: This feature is implicitly required by the WebGPU specification but it has relatively low coverage on Android with 60% of devices supporting it. I think we should remove it from the spec and ask that the firstInstance arguments to `DrawIndirect` and `DrawIndexedIndirect` be 0, otherwise the drawcall is nooped.

title: Spec doesn't compile
body:
After a `bikeshed update` running `bikeshed spec index.bs` produces the following error:

```
LINK ERROR: No 'idl' refs found for 'PredefinedColorSpace'.
{{PredefinedColorSpace}}
LINE ~5558: Couldn't find section '#premultiplied-alpha-and-the-2d-rendering-context' in spec 'html':
[[html#premultiplied-alpha-and-the-2d-rendering-context|always premultiplied]]
```

I know how to fix the first one but I don't know which HTML spec Bikeshed is using to check the second link. @kainino0x do you know?

title: No alignment constraints for setIndex/VertexBuffer offsets.
body:
At least Metal requires that the offset of vertex buffers must be a multiple of 4, but Vulkan expands on it a bit more:

> If format is a packed format, attribAddress must be a multiple of the size in bytes of the whole attribute data type as described in Packed Formats. Otherwise, attribAddress must be a multiple of the size in bytes of the component type indicated by format (see Formats).

WebGPU doesn't have packed vertex formats yet, so this means that the largest alignment required is 4.

For the index buffer Vulkan requires that the offset be a multiple of the size of a single index value and I suspect that's the same in all other APIs.

We should add these constraints in the spec.

title: Web IDL hiccup in GPUPresentationContext: Dictionary arguments cannot be nullable
"Sampled" is ambiguous in the spec

milestone.title: V1.0
milestone.description: Issues which at least one party wishes to make it into Version 1 of the API.

body: In the texture usage, `SAMPLED` merely means that a shader can read from the texture. It doesn't actually mean that the shader can use it with a sampler (which is another meaning for "sampled").

title: Errant reference to `break if` in WGSL spec
body: There is a  `break if (i == 5);` in the spec but I don't see it referenced anywhere else inside `EXAMPLE: VARIABLE INITIAL VALUES`.

title: Dispatch usage scopes contain unused bindgroups
body: At the moment the spec defines the usage scope for dispatches as the set of all the bind groups bound on the encoder, even if they aren't used by the dispatch. It should probably only count the bind groups that are used by the current pipeline's layout instead.

title: Metal is unable to copy depth formats into colors

milestone.title: V1.0
milestone.description: Issues which at least one party wishes to make it into Version 1 of the API.

body:
Currently the spec allows D32 -> R32 and D16 -> R16 copies.

On Metal, we generally implement copies between different formats by "casting" one of the sides to the other (i.e .[newTextureViewWithPixelFormat](https://developer.apple.com/documentation/metal/mtltexture/1515598-newtextureviewwithpixelformat?language=objc)], followed by the copy command on `BlitCommandEncoder`.

However, Metal defines "cast" only within certain groups, and it places color formats in a separate group from the depth formats. So we end up with:
> source texture pixelFormat (MTLPixelFormatDepth32Float) not castable

I suggest we remove any notion of Depth -> Color copies from the spec, at least for MVP, to address this.

title: Relax the out-of-bounds specification

labels.name: wgsl resolved
labels.description: Resolved - waiting for a change to the WGSL specification

milestone.title: V1.0
milestone.description: Issues which at least one party wishes to make it into Version 1 of the API.

body:
This is a follow-up from https://github.com/gpuweb/gpuweb/pull/1580#discussion_r611871488
Currently, WGSL spec only describes the clamping behavior. Instead, it should follow WebGPU group decision to allow any of the following behaviors:

- discard the whole draw call
- behave like RBA, which means reading can return anything within the buffer (not within the array), or zeroes, or other stuff
- behave like D3D, which means reading always returns zeroes, and writing is ignored

title: "workgroup_size" builtin is not supported on some Apple platforms
body:
The builtin translates to `dispatch_threads_per_threadgroup`, which is available on "All OS: Since Metal 1.0" according to the Metal language spec. However, actually using it gives me the following error:
> <stdin>:12:19: error: 'dispatch_threads_per_threadgroup' attribute requires Metal language standard macos-metal2.0 or higher
, type2 wg_size [[dispatch_threads_per_threadgroup]]

title: WebGPU should validate that storageTexture bindings have a single mip level.

milestone.title: V1.0
milestone.description: Issues which at least one party wishes to make it into Version 1 of the API.

body:
For example this `textureLoad` overload doesn't have a `level` parameter:

```rust
textureLoad(t : [[access(read)]] texture_storage_2d<F>, coords : vec2<i32>) -> vec4<T>
```

Shouldn't it instead be:

```rust
textureLoad(t : [[access(read)]] texture_storage_2d<F>, coords : vec2<i32>, level : i32) -> vec4<T>
```

Looking at the Vulkan and SPIRV specifications I don't see anything that would prevent this. This was discussed in https://github.com/gpuweb/gpuweb/pull/1032 where folks seemed to read the SPIRV spec as disallowing the `LOD` image operand for `OpImageRead` but that doesn't seem to be the case.

title: Specify what happens to mappings when the buffer is GCed.
body: Right not the spec doesn't have any text to explain what happens to a buffer's mappings when the buffer is GCed. Because the GC is unobservable, the mappings should not change but that's not written down.

title: GPUAdapterLimits uses GPUSize32 for read only attributes
Contradictions in the validation rules of copyTextureToTexture() with depth stencil formats

milestone.title: V1.0
milestone.description: Issues which at least one party wishes to make it into Version 1 of the API.

body:
I find there are two contradictions among [the validation rules of copyTextureToTexture()](https://gpuweb.github.io/gpuweb/#dom-gpucommandencoder-copytexturetotexture) and ["Depth/stencil formats"](https://gpuweb.github.io/gpuweb/#depth-formats). I think we should update the validation rules of copyTextureToTexture() to cover these special rules on depth/stencil formats.

The validation rules of copyTextureToTexture() says
- source.texture.format is **equal** to destination. texture.format".
- If source.texture.format is a depth-stencil format: source.aspect and destination.aspect must **both refer to all aspects** of source.texture.format and destination.texture.format, respectively.

While "Depth/stencil formats" says:
Copies between depth textures can only happen **within the following sets of formats**:
  - stencil8, depth24plus-stencil8 (**stencil component**), r8uint
  - depth16unorm, r16uint
  - depth24plus, depth24plus-stencil8 (**depth aspect**)

----

From #1692:

The "within the following sets of formats" section is wrong.

----

From #1479:

- Consider explicitly documenting that T2T copies with matching format is always valid (all formats, not just D/S)

title: access decorations for textures (text/example inconsistency)

milestone.title: V1.0
milestone.description: Issues which at least one party wishes to make it into Version 1 of the API.

body:
The WGSL spec says:

> The access decoration must only appear on a type used as the store type for a variable in the storage storage class.

But there are examples in the spec where access decorations are used on texture variables, which are (implicitly) in the handle storage class.

title: Typo on Division operation in the specs
body:
https://gpuweb.github.io/gpuweb/wgsl.html#arithmetic-expr
The Operation for floating point division should be OpFDiv, not OpFAdd.

title: beginRenderPass should validate that the attachment don't alias

milestone.title: V1.0
milestone.description: Issues which at least one party wishes to make it into Version 1 of the API.

body: Currently the specification allows using the same view for multiple attachments of a render pass. This seems like an issue, for example what does it mean if the same view is `loadValue: "load"` and `loadOp: [1.0, 0.0, 0.0, 1.0]`?

title: getExecutionTime requires encoding commands into an otherwise finished command buffer
body:
#870 introduced `getExecutionTime` as a method on `GPUCommandBuffer`. On Vulkan and D3D12 it would require the implementation to encode the timestamp commands, but on WebGPU side the `GPUCommandEncoder` is already closed.
This breaks our command encoding semantics, and I don't think needs to.
Instead, we should fix the `getExecutionTime` in a way that makes it known at the command encoding time. Also see https://github.com/gpuweb/gpuweb/issues/1325#issuecomment-755405647

title: The default values of GPUSamplerDescriptor.addressMode{U, V, W} are different from the ones in WebGL
body: In current WebGPU SPEC the default value of GPUSamplerDescriptor.addressMode{U, V, W} are all "[clamp-to-edge](https://gpuweb.github.io/gpuweb/#GPUSamplerDescriptor)", while in [WebGL 1.0](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebGLRenderingContext/texParameter) and [OpenGL ES 2.0 SPEC (chapter 3.7.6)](https://www.khronos.org/registry/OpenGL/specs/es/2.0/es_full_spec_2.0.pdf#nameddest=section-3.7.6), the default value of TEXTURE_WRAP_S and TEXTURE_WRAP_T are both GL_REPEAT. Is it intended to introduce such difference?

title: shader binding validation for multisampled texture seems weird/wrong
body:
If the binding member entry is texture, and entry.texture.mutisampled is:

* *true*: The binding is a sampled texture with a sample count of 1.
* *false* then "the binding is a multisampled texture"

That seems wrong ?

title: GPURenderBundleEncoder shouldn't have a [[command_encoder]]

milestone.title: V1.0
milestone.description: Issues which at least one party wishes to make it into Version 1 of the API.

body:
`GPUProgrammablePassEncoder` has a `[[command_encoder]]` internal slot, but `GPURenderBundleEncoder` is a `GPUProgrammablePassEncoder` and should not have one.

Not sure what needs to be done about this.

title: Unable to use [SameObject] on "readonly attribute GPUError error"

milestone.title: V1.0
milestone.description: Issues which at least one party wishes to make it into Version 1 of the API.

body:
See the spec - https://heycam.github.io/webidl/#SameObject
`[SameObject]` is only valid on properties that are interfaces or objects. In our case, it's:
```
typedef (GPUOutOfMemoryError or GPUValidationError) GPUError;
```

title: Primitive cut values for non-strip topologies
body:
Originally, we requited the index format be provided at pipeline creation, and not in `setIndexBuffer`. Then #943 and #940 changed this to be only required for strip topologies, and in addition `setIndexBuffer` got this as an argument.

However, a concern recently got brought up by @Kangz that [Metal forces](https://developer.apple.com/documentation/metal/mtlrendercommandencoder/1515520-drawindexedprimitives?language=objc) the primitive cut value to be effective even for non-strip topologies:
> Primitive restart functionality is enabled with the largest unsigned integer index value, relative to indexType (0xFFFF for MTLIndexTypeUInt16 or 0xFFFFFFFF for MTLIndexTypeUInt32). This feature finishes drawing the current primitive at the specified index and starts drawing a new one with the next index.

I did a bit of investigation on other backends as well. [Vulkan appears to specify](https://www.khronos.org/registry/vulkan/specs/1.2-extensions/man/html/VkPipelineInputAssemblyStateCreateInfo.html) the cut value independent of the topology as well:
> `primitiveRestartEnable` controls whether a special vertex index value is treated as restarting the assembly of primitives. This enable only applies to indexed draws

Finally, D3D12 isn't specifying exactly what happens for non-strip topologies. It [only says](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/api/d3d12/ne-d3d12-d3d12_index_buffer_strip_cut_value) what happens for strip ones. I reached out to Microsoft on discord, and got pointed to [D3D11 functional spec](https://microsoft.github.io/DirectX-Specs/d3d/archive/D3D11_3_FunctionalSpec.htm), which does specify the same behaviour as Vulkan:
> Even if the current Primitive Topology is not a strip, then the cut index value still takes effect, potentially resulting in an incomplete primitive (see next section). Thus, handling of the cut is kept orthogonal to primitive topology, even though it is not useful for some of them.
> Note that providing a behavior for the cut value when used with a non-strip topology is a way of saying that the behavior is defined, allowing hardware to keep the cut behavior always enabled. In practice though, using cut for a list topology is obviously not a "feature" that it would ever make sense for an application to author to.

With that in mind, I suggest to simply revert #940 and #943 to the old semantics, which appears to be portable across the APIs. Primitive cut values will therefore always be enabled by the WebGPU implementations, to match Metal restrictions.

title: Sampling non-float textures is forbidden in HLSL
body:
Currently, the spec has `GPUTextureComponentType` that has to be provided for "sampled" texture types. @eseaflower pointed to an issue with HLSL that non-float textures can't be sampled at all in https://github.com/gfx-rs/wgpu/issues/999#issuecomment-713685639

Looking at the documentation, I see that only "float" types are permitted here:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/direct3dhlsl/samplelevel-s-float-float-int-uint-

Technically, we can work around this by issuing `Load` instructions, but this requires a bunch of logic and information about the texture dimensions and sampler wrapping modes, so it would be very unfortunate if we had to do this.

I think we should just restrict this in WGSL by defining the `textureSample*` to only work on `f32` textures and return `vec4<f32>` correspondingly.

There is another problem with "sampled-texture" binding in WebGPU now: these textures can't really be sampled (if we go with the restriction), so binding them via this type is awkward and confusing.

title: T2B/B2T copies should require whole-subresource copies for depth/stencil
body:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/api/d3d12/nf-d3d12-id3d12graphicscommandlist-copytextureregion

> Note that for a depth-stencil buffer, the depth and stencil planes are separate subresources within the buffer.
> 
> To copy an entire resource, rather than just a region of a subresource, we recommend to use CopyResource instead.
> 
> Note  If you use CopyTextureRegion with a depth-stencil buffer or a multisampled resource, you must copy the entire subresource rectangle.

I thought we had this validation in our spec but I can't find it.

title: GPUDevice.createBindGroup doesn't validate the resource's type.
body: In the validation for `GPUDevice.createBindGroup` there is no validation for the resource type, so it is valid to pass a buffer for a texture bindings (or at least the spec will try to use `GPUTexture` members on the `GPUBuffer`).

title: Compatible usage rules are unimplementable in D3D12
body:
(without pipeline recompilation)

When compiling a pipeline against layout using a `readonly-storage-buffer` binding type, we need to make a choice in D3D12: make it use a `u` UAV register or a `s` SRV register.

 - If we're using a `u` register, then the buffer must be in the `D3D12_RESOURCE_STATE_UNORDERED_ACCESS` state which isn't allowed to be used with readonly states, and conflicts with this compatible usage set: *"Each usage in U is input, constant, storage-read, or attachment-read."*
 - If we're using a `s` register, then the buffer must be in  either the `D3D12_RESOURCE_STATE_NON_PIXEL_SHADER_RESOURCE` or
`D3D12_RESOURCE_STATE_PIXEL_SHADER_RESOURCE`
 state which isn't allowed to be used with read/write states, and conflicts with this compatible usage set: *"Each usage in U is storage or storage-read."*

@RafaelCintron @damyanp is there any way around this? It's pretty restrictive considering buffers always have a linear layout.

Otherwise I think we should remove *"Each usage in U is storage or storage-read."* from the list as the purpose of `readonly-storage-buffer` is that it can be used at the same time as other readonly states.

title: Separate linear sampler binding type?
body:
### Problem
Linear sampling (or "filtering") can only be done with textures that have `GPUTextureComponentType.float`. The shaders know about the component type of textures, but the shaders don't know if a sampler is filtering or not. So shader translation can't validate this, and outside of the shader, on the API side, we no longer know which textures are used with which samplers.

### Solutions
  1. allow the filtering to be done on non-float textures, specify this as "undefined result" or something. It may be unfeasible if there is an UB in the driver/HW, and it's obviously not very portable (but the choice is provided for completeness!).
  2. have the shader translation to generate a map of texture-sampler pairs, which will then be used by the validation at the draw time (!) where all the bindings are known, and we can check the samplers.
  3. introduce a new `GPUBindingType::"filtering-sampler"` (in addition to regular "sampler" and "comparison-sampler") with the corresponding distinction in WGSL. This would mean:
    - `createShaderModule` can fail if we see that a filtering sampler is used with an incompatible texture
    - `createBindGroupLayout` can fail if the given sampler doesn't match the binding
    - no heavy validation at draw time

### Details
If we go (3) one concern could be raised about how the translation from other languages, like SPIR-V, would know what type of the sampler to use. To some extent, it fits under the current umbrella of sampler diversity (we have a "comparison" sampler type that SPIR-V doesn't). As proposed in #889, we could generate multiple conflicting bindings for the SPIR-V sampler, and it will all work fine as long as only one of the multiple (regular/comparison/filtering) is used statically for any given entry point.

title: Sampling from MSAA textures
body:
I realized that the MSAA textures are in a weird position: they are "sampled texture" binding types on both the API and shaders sides today, but they can't really be sampled. In GLSL, they can also be "texel fetched", which corresponds to a `texture_load` in WGSL today, which the grammar only allows to happen on storage textures (with a TODO related to sampled and multi-sampled textures).

## Proposal
Here is a way we could resolve this:
  1. have a separate "multisampled-texture" binding type, Edit: and remove the "multisampled" flag
  2. have a separate corresponding set of types on WGSL. That would mean `texture_sample` is no longer applicable to it, which is what we need.
  3. have `texture_load` functions overloaded to work on multisampled textures. They need an extra "sample ID" integer parameter for these overloads. They would also need to be overloaded for regular sampled textures.

title: Set negative GPURenderPassColorAttachmentDescriptor.loadValue for unsigned integer formats

milestone.title: V1.0
milestone.description: Issues which at least one party wishes to make it into Version 1 of the API.

body:
Hi WebGPU CG,

I'd like to report an issue about clearing the color attachments with unsigned integer formats in WebGPU in a render pass. When we use a negative value in the ```loadValue``` for the color attachments in unsigned integer formats, we will see different behaviors on D3D12 and Metal. According to my experiments, on D3D12 this value will always be treated as 0, but on Metal it won't.

Note that on Vulkan we can always set the correct clear color with the union members of [```VkClearColor```](https://www.khronos.org/registry/vulkan/specs/1.2-extensions/man/html/VkClearColorValue.html) for float, signed integer and unsigned integer formats, so it is not a problem for Vulkan.

So it seems we need some validations on the ```loadValue``` to ensure we have the same definite behavior on D3D12, Metal and Vulkan. What do you think?

title: [wgsl] Fix definition of const_expr
body:
This CL updates the const_expr to use the proper * instead of ?.

Fixes #800

title: [wgsl] Fix rendering of FLOAT_LITERAL.
body: Fixex #816

title: Consistent definitions of the methods

milestone.title: V1.0
milestone.description: Issues which at least one party wishes to make it into Version 1 of the API.

body:
Apparently we use different definitions for the methods:
  - names with empty braces, e.g. `{{GPUCommandEncoder/copyBufferToTexture()}}`
  - names with all the parameters, e.g. `{{GPUComputePassEncoder/dispatch(x, y, z)}}`

I haven't found any `{{Something/method}}` cases (without braces).
We should try to make it consistent, i.e. use the `{{Something/method()}}` form everywhere.

title: Anisotropic clamping for SamplerDescriptor
body:
We have the anisotropic extension string, but no associated API to set the clamp.
I wonder how this will be specified: just adding a member to `SamplerDescriptor` may look like this is a part of the core spec.

See: #202

title: Figure out the base vertex input limits
body:
We've been asked to clarify the baseline for:
  - max number of vertex buffers
  - max number of vertex attributes
  - max attribute offset
  - max stride

title: Difference between the source and destination array layer count in GPUTextureViewDescriptor
body:
This is a follow-up to #613
We have `GPUTextureViewDescriptor.arrayLayerCount`, which gets confusing in case we are viewing a 2D array texture as a cube array view. From the user perspective, it's not clear whether it means the number of images in the source 2D array, or the number of layers in the resulting view (number of cubes).

title: Naming inconsistency in GPUBindGroupLayoutBinding
body:
(copy-paste from #WebGPU:matrix.org)


I just stumbled over a naming inconsistency in GPUBindGroupLayoutBinding (https://gpuweb.github.io/gpuweb/#dictdef-gpubindgrouplayoutbinding):

The member for the texture-view-dimension is of type GPUTextureViewDimension, but the name is textureDimension, which is confusing because there's also a type GPUTextureDimension. The naming caused me to accidently put an enum-value for GPUTextureDimenstion into that field.

...I stumbled over this via Dawns C-API (because C enums are not strong typed), but since in JS these are strings and not strongly typed either, a similar problem can happen there).

title: STORAGE_READ usages for buffers and textures
body:
Partially implemented by #532 (textures only, also I think we can bikeshed the name).
Related to #513, also distantly to #514 

#303 introduced the read-only bindings. So technically, today, when there is a `STORAGE` usage, it could be read-only, or it could be read-write. The difference affects whether we allow any other usage to co-exist within the synchronization scope. Therefore it's difficult to both reason about and properly specify `STORAGE` usage today.

We could make this entirely clear by splitting the `STORAGE_READ` out of `STORAGE`, leaving the latter to be strictly mutable.

title: Metal Validation Layers require sourceBytesPerImage >= 512 bytes

milestone.title: V1.0
milestone.description: Issues which at least one party wishes to make it into Version 1 of the API.

body:
Ran into this undocumented restriction when running with Metal validation layers:
```
-[MTLDebugBlitCommandEncoder validateCopyFromBuffer:sourceOffset:sourceBytesPerRow:sourceBytesPerImage:sourceSize:toTexture:destinationSlice:destinationLevel:destinationOrigin:options:]:532: failed assertion `sourceBytesPerImage(448) must be >= (512).'
Process 31489 stopped
* thread #1, queue = 'com.apple.main-thread', stop reason = signal SIGABRT
    frame #0: 0x00007fff5e1df2c2 libsystem_kernel.dylib`__pthread_kill + 10
libsystem_kernel.dylib`__pthread_kill:
->  0x7fff5e1df2c2 <+10>: jae    0x7fff5e1df2cc            ; <+20>
    0x7fff5e1df2c4 <+12>: movq   %rax, %rdi
    0x7fff5e1df2c7 <+15>: jmp    0x7fff5e1d9453            ; cerror_nocancel
    0x7fff5e1df2cc <+20>: retq   
```

Also, sourceBytesPerRow must be >= 64, but that's fine because WebGPU has rowPitch be a multiple of 256.

This has some validation implications on permissible values for `imageHeight` or (`zPitch` in #519), and it also means that `imageHeight == 0` cannot truly mean "tightly packed" in #517.

title: GPUVertexBufferDescriptor 's stride size needs to be a multiple of 4 bytes
body: Metal has requests [here](https://developer.apple.com/documentation/metal/mtlvertexbufferlayoutdescriptor/1515441-stride) that stride size of vertex buffer needs to be a multiple of  4 bytes. WebGPU should also follow the restriction.

title: Number.MAX_VALUE is not valid WebIDL
body:
I was taking a look at (https://github.com/gpuweb/gpuweb/issues/87) and ran into the problem that
`Number.MAX_VALUE` is not valid WebIDL according to [the spec](https://www.w3.org/TR/WebIDL-1/#prod-float) , yet it is used in the `sketch.webidl` [here](https://github.com/gpuweb/gpuweb/blob/master/design/sketch.webidl#L192)

Not sure if there is a better solution, just wanted to flag this since it prevents running validation.

title: WebGPUCommandEncoderDescriptor doesn't appear to be defined anywhere in the sketch IDL
body:
https://github.com/gpuweb/gpuweb/blob/8ffe46f0aa74f949055625fa6c32b57fd00c57d9/design/sketch.webidl#L500

I ⌘-F'ed for it, but didn't see any definition.
